coredata.dc:title: Regulated lithium deposition behavior by chlorinated hybrid solid-electrolyte-interphase for stable lithium metal anode

Zhao, Bing
Zhang, Jiujun
coredata.dc:description: Lithium (Li) metal is the ultimate anode material for use in next-generation batteries in the pursuit of higher energy densities. However, the traditional solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) owns the disadvantages of large interfacial impedance, low Li ions migration rate and easy fragility. Herein, this is the first report that reveals in detail the rationality of Li deposition beneath the chlorinated hybrid layer and fast ion transport kinetics at LiCl/Li interface through density functional theory (DFT) estimation. Based on this, an artificial SEI layer enriched with LiCl, LiZn alloy and in-situ ring-opening polymerization of poly(tetrahydrofuran) (PTMG) is constructed on lithium metal surface. The glow-discharge optical emission spectroscopy (GD-OES) results revealed that LiCl is mainly enriched on the surface of the artificial SEI, its excellent electron-blocking ability could inhibit the electron flow tunneling from the Li metal to SEI, which prevents the generation of Li0. As expected, the Li metal anode with an artificial chlorinated hybrid SEI layer exhibits excellent cycle performance over 2000 h with lower overpotential of 11 mV at 1 mA cm−2. Moreover, full-cell delivers higher capacity retention and coulombic efficiency after long cycles under high LiFePO4 loading (at 17.4 mg cm−2, 3.0 mAh cm−2).

xocs:item-toc-entry.xocs:item-toc-section-title: Interfacial transport properties of Li ions in chlorinated hybrid SEI
Design and characterization of an artificial chlorinated hybrid SEI
Li deposition behaviors and long-cycle properties
Preparation of composite lithium metal electrodes

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Adsorption and migration properties of Li+ in chlorinated SEI and Li/LiCl interface. a) Different adsorption sites and corresponding adsorption energies of Li+ on LiCl (001) and Li (001) surfaces. The inset shows top-view modes of LiCl (001) (left) and Li (001) (right). Migration potential barriers of Li+ in b) LiCl bulk and c) Li/LiCl interface (the insets are the specific migration paths). d) Partial density of states (PDOS) of the Li/LiCl interface. e) Structural model of the Li/LiCl interface. f) Charge density difference at the Li/LiCl interface. The yellow spheres represent the aggregation of charge and the blue represents the loss of charge. The isosurface level is 0.002e Å−3. Atoms in green = Cl and purple = Li.

Fabrication and functional schematic of the chlorinated hybrid SEI. a) In-situ preparation process of the artificial SEI layer. Schematic diagrams of Li deposition at the b) treated Li and c) fresh Li electrodes. d) The reaction mechanism scheme illustrates the formation of the hybrid SEI composed of LiZn alloy, LiCl and PTMG.

Structural and morphological properties of the artificially chlorinated hybrid SEI layer. a) XRD pattern, b) Raman spectroscopy and c) high-resolution C 1 s XPS spectrum of treated Li metal. SEM images of the treated Li metal before cycling. d) Top-view SEM image and the elemental mapping of the treated Li, e) cross-sectional SEM image. The scale bars are 10 μm. f) The elemental distribution in the chlorinated artificial mixed layer with GD-OES test time. g) Tafel profiles of treated Li (red line) and fresh Li (black line). EIS of the Li-Li symmetric cells for h) treated Li and i) fresh Li over 168 h of rest.

Li deposition morphologies of the treated Li with chlorinated SEI layer after 50 cycles at a current density of 1 mA cm−2. a), c) Top-view SEM images and the elemental mapping, b) cross-sectional SEM image. Electrochemical performance of Li symmetric cells. d), e) Voltage-cycle time profiles of the treated Li and fresh Li electrodes at d) 1 mA cm−2 and e) 2 mA cm−2, respectively. f) SEM images of the fresh and treated Li electrodes at the 1st, 10th, and 100th Li deposition states. The scale bars are 10 μm.

Battery performance comparison of Li|LiFePO4 full cells using fresh Li and treated Li metal anodes. a) Long-term cycling performance at a current density of 0.5C. b), c) Charge/discharge voltage profiles at 5th and 100th cycles at 0.5C. d) Rate capability comparison and e), f) the corresponding charge/discharge voltage profiles at different current density rates from 0.2C to 3C, at 0.1C constant discharge current density.

head.ce:title: Regulated lithium deposition behavior by chlorinated hybrid solid-electrolyte-interphase for stable lithium metal anode

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Shanghai University, Shanghai 200444, China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Lithium (Li) metal is the ultimate anode material for use in next-generation batteries in the pursuit of higher energy densities. However, the traditional solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) owns the disadvantages of large interfacial impedance, low Li ions migration rate and easy fragility. Herein, this is the first report that reveals in detail the rationality of Li deposition beneath the chlorinated hybrid layer and fast ion transport kinetics at LiCl/Li interface through density functional theory (DFT) estimation. Based on this, an artificial SEI layer enriched with LiCl, LiZn alloy and in-situ ring-opening polymerization of poly(tetrahydrofuran) (PTMG) is constructed on lithium metal surface. The glow-discharge optical emission spectroscopy (GD-OES) results revealed that LiCl is mainly enriched on the surface of the artificial SEI, its excellent electron-blocking ability could inhibit the electron flow tunneling from the Li metal to SEI, which prevents the generation of Li0. As expected, the Li metal anode with an artificial chlorinated hybrid SEI layer exhibits excellent cycle performance over 2000 h with lower overpotential of 11 mV at 1 mA cm−2. Moreover, full-cell delivers higher capacity retention and coulombic efficiency after long cycles under high LiFePO4 loading (at 17.4 mg cm−2, 3.0 mAh cm−2).

ce:section.ce:para: With the rapid development of electric vehicles (EV) and large-scale energy storage systems, there is a growing demand for high energy density rechargeable batteries [1,2]. However, the energy density of existing commercially available Li-ion batteries is still insufficient for these applications [3,4]. Lithium (Li) metal has been considered a promising anode material for high energy density storage systems due to its high specific capacity (3860 mAh g−1), the lowest reduction potential (3.04 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode) and smallest density of any metal in nature [5,6]. Unfortunately, the continuous granulation, uncontrolled growth of needle-like dendrites and continuous side reactions of lithium metal anodes during long cycles, generally lead to low coulombic efficiency (CE), high interfacial impedance, short-circuit and even fire breakout. Moreover, due to the high activity of lithium metal, it is easy to react spontaneously with electrolyte and generate unstable SEI, which seriously limits the commercial application of lithium metal anodes [7].

In the past few years, many strategies have been proposed to solve the SEI instability and volume expansion issues of lithium metal anodes. Such as, selecting carefully the electrolyte additives (LiI, RbF and SiCl4) to improve the ionic conductivity and rigidity of the SEI [8–10], constructing of a three-dimensional (3D) structured collector to buffer anode volume expansion and reduce local current density [11–14], establishing functional separator to suppress the growth of lithium dendrites and short circuit [15,16]. All of the above approaches can alleviate the problems of lithium metal anode, but the improvement of performance is still very limited. Such as the electrolyte additive should have a higher reduction potential relative to the organic electrolyte, which is highly exhausted during the charging/discharging process, not conducive to the formation of stable SEI [16,17]. Ideally, the SEI should meet the following requirements: (1) thickness controllability to reduce interfacial impedance; (2) chemical stability to decrease side reactions; (3) high ionic conductivity and electronic insulation to inhibit dendrite generation. To achieve this, researchers are gradually turning their attention to artificial SEI layer. Such as, Kozen and co-workers [18] designed a nano-thickness Al2O3 protection layer on the surface of lithium metal via atomic layer deposition. Cui’s group [19] constructed a hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) and graphene ultrathin SEI layer by chemical vapor deposition. However, constructing a stable lithium anode with a simple and low-cost solution remains a challenge [20].

Recently, we had noticed that artificial SEIs containing lithophilic alloys (Li/Zn, Li/In, Li/Bi, Li/As and Li/Sn) and lithium halides (LiF or LiCl) can be prepared by a simple solid–liquid reaction, which can effectively inhibit dendrite growth and have good electrochemical stability [21–25]. For example, Xiong’s group constructed Li3Sb and LiF hybrid layer on the lithium metal surface by solid–liquid reaction, and the excellent electron-blocking ability of the LiF component reduced the electron attack on the SEI layer [26]. Liang's team introduced Li x M alloy (where M = In, Zn, Bi or As) and LiCl layer on the lithium metal surface, and thanks to the electron insulating property of LiCl, lithium deposition underneath this hybrid SEI layer was demonstrated [21,27]. Xie's team achieved excellent electrochemical performance by constructing an organic–inorganic hybrid layer containing LiCl on the lithium metal surface through a simple chemical modification strategy [23]. On one hand, lithium alloys enables rapid movement of lithium ions on the surface of artificial interfacial layers with a low diffusion energy barriers [27]. The homogeneous nucleation theory relates the growth of dendrites to the ratio of diffusion coefficient D and deposition flux F (D/F) [28,29]. According to homogeneous nucleation theory, there is a competitive relationship between the diffusion and deposition behavior of lithium. Once the deposition behavior dominates, the growth of dendrites occurs. This is the reason why dendrites tend to grow under high-rate charge/discharge conditions. On the other hand, LiF and LiCl have certain electron insulating properties, which can regulate the electric field distribution at the interface, enabling the lithium metal to deposited under the lithium alloy layer [21]. In addition, artificial SEI may isolate the lithium metal from electrolyte and prevent side reactions. However, there is no clear information on the driving force for lithium deposition beneath the composite layer composed of lithophilic alloy and ion-conductive lithium halides.

Herein, we firstly attempt to understand the dynamic behaviors of lithium at the artificial chlorinated hybrid SEI/Li interface at the atomic scale. The DFT calculations were employed to compare the adsorption energy of lithium on the surface of Li metal and LiCl, reveal the migration barrier of lithium through the SEI/Li interface, elaborating the rationality of lithium deposition beneath the hybrid layer. On this basis, a hybrid protective layer composed of LiZn alloy, LiCl and PTMG was experimentally designed on the surface of lithium metal (noted as the ‘Treated Li’) by a fast dip-coating process (within 20 s), during which the flexible and conductive PTMG was obtained by using epichlorohydrin (ECH) to initiate ring-opening of tetrahydrofuran (THF) in the presence of the Lewis acid ZnCl2 at room temperature. Benefiting from low diffusion barrier of LiZn alloy, high electrical insulation of LiCl and good mechanical property of PTMG, the treated lithium anodes express negligible volume change and dendrite free properties during long cycles. Superior cycling stability over 2000 h at 1 mA cm−2 in symmetric battery and 300 cycles at 0.5C in Li|LiFePO4 full cell (at high loading of 17.4 mg cm−2, 3.0 mAh cm−2) were exhibited, suggesting the promising feasibility of the chlorinated hybrid SEI modification strategy.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Interfacial transport properties of Li ions in chlorinated hybrid SEI
ce:section.ce:para: In the lithophilic alloy/lithium halide hybrid protective layer, the lithium alloy can homogenize the electron distribution and drive lithium ions to move rapidly across its surface without further nucleation. On the other hand, the electrically insulating nature of lithium halide creates a potential gradient across the hybrid layer, the two together direct homogeneous deposition of lithium [21]. However, it still lacks information to understand that lithium halide salt has the ability to drive lithium deposition under the hybrid protective layer from a kinetic point of view. Therefore, it is necessary to investigate the kinetic behavior of lithium at the interface layer. In general, the atomic plane with the lowest surface energy is the most stable and easily exposed site [30,31]. By calculating the Wulf structure of Li metal, the surface energies of (001), (110), and (111) planes are 37.01, 41.28 and 42.76 meV/Å2, respectively [32]. The most stable atomic plane Li (001) was chosen for the DFT calculations. For the same reason, the LiCl (001) plane was chosen to be studied for both the surface and the interface models [30]. Detailed parameters of Li and LiCl are described in the Supplementary Information Table S1.

In order to gain insight into the ability of LiCl to guide lithium deposition underneath artificial SEI layers, the adsorption energy of Li at different adsorption sites on Li metal and LiCl surfaces was systematically investigated via DFT calculations. Owing to symmetry, the hollow, bridge and top adsorption sites are investigated in the surface model to simulate the adsorption behavior of the lithium adatom on Li (001) and LiCl (001) surfaces (Fig. S1). The 3 × 3 × 1Li (001) and 2 × 2 × 1LiCl (001) supercell models were constructed to eliminate the effect of periodic boundaries when calculating the adsorption energy of lithium on Li metal and LiCl surfaces, respectively. The magnitude of the atomic adsorption energy affects the deposition behavior of Li atoms during plating. As shown in Fig. 1 a, it is clear that Li tends to adsorb at the LiCl-bridge site or top of Cl atom on the LiCl (001) surface to obtain the stable adsorption structure, the corresponding adsorption energies are −0.246 and −0.253 eV, respectively. Furthermore, the adsorption behavior of Li on the surface of Li (001) was also considered. The adsorption energies were −1.454, −1.399 and −1.465 eV, corresponding to adsorption sites at Li-hollow, Li-bridge and Li2nd-top, respectively, which are all greater than that of LiCl (001). Therefore, the large adsorption energy leads to preferential adsorption, nucleation, and deposition of Li atoms on the surface Li (001) surfaces [33], proving that Li+ have an original driving force for top-down motion in chlorinated SEI.

Furthermore, the LiCl/Li interface model is constructed to investigate the migration characteristics of Li+ at the interface between the chlorinated SEI and the Li metal anode. In constructing the interface model, the lattice matching degree needs to be satisfied in order to obtain a realistic crystal interface model. The interface model is shown in Fig. 1e, and the lattice mismatch is calculated to be 0.15%, which meets the requirement of<5% [34]. As shown in Fig. 1b and c, the migration potential barrier of lithium at the LiCl/Li interface is 0.142 eV, which is much smaller than that of lithium in the LiCl bulk phase (0.678 eV). This clearly highlights the superiorities of the LiCl/Li interface: lower interfacial impedance, higher ion migration rate and fast ion transport channels, which accelerate the rapid migration Li+and facilitates the uniform distribution. The correctness of the kinetics of top-down migration of lithium ions was further verified.

In addition, to verify the interaction between Li metal and LiCl at the LiCl/Li interface, the partial density of states (PDOS) was calculated for the Li-2 s orbitals in the Li metal and the Cl-3p orbitals in the LiCl layer at the interface (see in Fig. 1d and e). As a result, the distribution of Li-2 s orbitals and Cl-3p orbitals has crossing each other, indicating that the Cl atoms at the interface would interact with the Li metal anode. This means that after the formation of the LiCl/Li interface structure, charge transfer occurs at the interface. The charge density difference visualized in Fig. 1f shows that the strong interfacial interaction between the Li (001) and LiCl (001) surfaces and a charge-rich region is formed at the Li/LiCl interface that is favorable for Li deposition.

These results indicate that the rapid diffusion of Li+ and the increase in charge concentration at the Li/SEI interface are expected to be achieved in the presence of chlorinated SEI, which is conducive to top-down migration of lithium ions and deposition of lithium metal underneath the artificial SEI [33,35].Therefore, during the deposition process, lithium is more easily deposited underneath the artificial SEI without dendrite generation.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Design and characterization of an artificial chlorinated hybrid SEI
ce:section.ce:para: In order to construct a layer of chlorinated hybrid SEI on the surface of lithium metal, ZnCl2 was selected as the reactant to produce LiCl and LiZn alloy via the conversion reaction with Li metal, THF was chosen as monomer to produce flexible PTMG and ECH acts as initiator. The preparation strategy and schematic diagram of the Li+ deposition of the treated Li and fresh Li is shown in Fig. 2 a-c. LiZn alloy is commonly used for the modification of Li anodes because of its excellent surface diffusion properties and little volume change. When Li foil is immersed in the THF mixed solution system (within 20 s), ZnCl2 undergoes a rapid conversion reaction, resulting in a uniform distribution of LiZn alloy and LiCl on the surface of lithium metal. Meanwhile, LiCl as a nucleophilic reagent, Zn2+ as a strong Lewis acid and ECH as an initiator, all of which can effectively trigger the ring-opening polymerization of THF (Fig. 2d) and formation of PTMG [36]. Note that PTMG has a large number of C–O bonds, so it has a strong adsorption ability with lithium [23]. Compared with the traditional Li deposition situation, the artificial SEI composed of LiZn alloy and LiCl could homogenize Li+ ions flux, accelerate ions transport rate within SEI and at the SEI/Li interface under the drive force of gradient LiCl concentration, thus promoting Li deposition underneath the chlorinated artificial SEI. Meanwhile, PTMG with good flexibility helps to tolerate the volumetric change and inhibits the formation of Li dendrites, these three components together form an ultra-stable artificial SEI layer.

Different component characterizations were performed to confirm the production of LiZn alloy phase and LiCl in the hybrid SEI layer. X-ray diffraction (XRD) results show that characteristic peaks of LiZn alloy and LiCl can be clearly observed (Fig. 3 a). The diffraction peaks at ∼ 41.1°, 48.3°, 59.1° and 74.7° correspond to LiZn alloy (JCPDS no: 03–0954); and three inconspicuous peaks at ∼ 30.1°, 34.8° and 50.2° are attributed to LiCl (JCPDS no: 04–0664), indicating successful conversion and alloying reaction between ZnCl2 and Li metal at room temperature. The in-situ ring-opening polymerization reaction of PTMG was confirmed by Raman spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The Raman stretching vibration peak located at 2898.2 and 1968.2 cm−1 can be assigned to long-chain alkyl –CH2– group (Fig. 3b). In addition, peaks at ∼ 913.8 cm−1, 891.7 cm−1 and 547.0 cm−1 are associated with stretching vibrations of C–C, C–O–C and Li–O covalent bonds [37,38], respectively. The XPS as shown in Fig. 3c presents high-resolution C 1 s spectrum of the treated Li. Three distinct peaks at 289.6, 286.4, and 285.0 eV correspond to C–Cl, C–O, and –CH2– bonds, respectively [23,39]. The presence of a large number of C–O bonds in the hybrid layer facilitates the uniform adsorption of Li+.

Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) are conducted to observe the surface and cross-section morphologies of the treated Li electrode. It can be found that the treated Li is uniformly coated by artificial SEI with smooth and flat surface (Fig. 3d and Fig. S2). Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping presents a uniform distribution of C, Zn, O and Cl in the hybrid layer (Fig. 3d). The cross-sectional image (Fig. 3e) shows that the thickness of the hybrid layer is ≈10 μm. In addition, the glow-discharge optical emission spectroscopy (GD-OES) technique results indicate that there is a concentration gradient distribution of LiCl in the hybrid protective layer with a higher concentration of LiCl on the surface of the artificial SEI (Fig. 3f). However, LiCl and PTMG has electronically insulating properties with a band gap value of 6.24 and 4.59 eV, respectively, as confirmed by density of state (DOS) estimation (Fig. S3). Therefore, chlorinated hybrid SEI can effectively inhibit the reduction of Li+ to Li0 on the surface of SEI, which facilitates the deposition of Li+ beneath the chlorinated artificial SEI layer.

To better understand the mechanism of the superior ionic conductivity of the artificial chlorinated SEI layer, the exchange current density of the treated Li and fresh Li electrodes were measured. Tafel curves (Fig. 3g) shows that the exchange current density of the treated Li (≈ 2.409 mA cm−2) is significantly higher than that of fresh Li electrode (≈ 0.459 mA cm−2), which implies that the artificial hybrid layer has a higher charge transfer rate and a fast Li-ion transport pathway. In addition, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of the Li-Li symmetric cells at different rest time were investigated to understand the chemical stability of the artificial hybrid SEI layer. As shown in Fig. 3h and i, the interfacial charge transport resistance (Rct ) of treated Li is 7.5 Ω after 0.5 h of rest, and the Rct has a negligible change after 168 h of rest, showing that the artificial SEI has high chemical stability [23,24]. Furthermore, the low interfacial transport impedance of treated Li is due to the fast Li-ion transport channels provided by LiZn and LiCl. In contrast, fresh Li electrode exhibits high interfacial charge transfer resistance and low chemical stability. Due to the absence of artificial SEI protection, the Rct change of fresh Li is significantly increased from 170 to 268 Ω as the rest time prolonging from 0.5 h to 168 h. Therefore, the artificial interface layer is able to isolate the lithium metal from the electrolyte and prevent the occurrence of side reactions.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Li deposition behaviors and long-cycle properties
ce:section.ce:para: To verify that the lithium deposition behavior occurs underneath the artificial chlorinated hybrid layer, SEM and EDS were employed to characterize the morphology and elemental distribution of treated Li after plating. Treated Li cell was symmetrically assembled and conducted charging/discharging for 50 cycles at a current density of 1 mA cm−2. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the surface of treated Li after plating is still compact and smooth with no obvious dendrites. There is a presumption here that once the lithium deposition behavior occurs on the surface of the hybrid layer rather than underneath it, the chlorinated hybrid SEI will be covered by lithium metal. This implies that the treated Li surface will not appear obvious characteristic elements of the artificial SEI compositions, especially Zn and Cl. However, the EDS mapping (Fig. 4c) shows that the treated Li surface after plating is still uniformly distributed with C, Zn, O and Cl elements, which indicates that the lithium deposition behavior occurs underneath the hybrid layer rather than on its surface. Furthermore, the cross-sectional view of treated Li (Fig. 4b) after electrodeposition with 1 mAh cm−2 lithium clearly demonstrates that the lithium is deposited below the hybrid layer rather than on the surface. More importantly, the thickness of the chlorinated hybrid SEI remains unchanged at about 10 μm after 50 plating/stripping cycles, which indicates that the hybrid layer is not only able to drive the top-down movement of lithium ions, but also has strong electrochemical stability, avoiding the direct contact between the lithium metal anode and the electrolyte and achieving dendrite free during the cycle.

To further investigate the stability of the artificial SEI layer, the treated Li and fresh Li were assembled into symmetric cells and galvanostatic charging/discharging at different areal current densities ranged from 1 to 5 mA cm−2. Fig. 4d and e shows the plating/stripping voltage profile of two kinds of cells at current densities of 1 mA cm−2 and 2 mA cm−2, respectively. It is clear that the treated Li symmetric cell exhibits longer and more stable plating/stripping cycling performance than that with fresh Li. In fresh Li cell, the voltage exhibits a wide range of fluctuations with increasing cycle time, and the overpotential increases rapidly, which leads to the early death of cell after running at 1 mA cm−2 and 2 mA cm−2 within 180 cycles simultaneously. In contrast, the treated Li symmetric cell can plate/strip stably for 2000 h and 1000 h without significant overpotential at 1 mA cm−2 and 2 mA cm−2, respectively. Meanwhile, the local scale-up plating/stripping voltage profiles of treated Li and fresh Li at different cycle durations are shown in Fig. S4. In fresh Li electrode, the SEI will repeatedly break down and repair since it's not stable enough, and the freshly deposited lithium has a persistent side reaction with the electrolyte, leading to increased interfacial resistance. Eventually, the overpotential increases rapidly, the electrolytes dry out, and even cell death occurs. In contrast, the artificial SEI with high stability can physically protect lithium metal from direct contact with the electrolyte, thus eliminating the occurrence of side reactions. This is why our electrochemical performance is significantly better compared to the current study (Fig. S11 and Table S2). In addition, due to the low surface diffusion barriers of LiZn and LiCl, about 0.023 eV and 0.08 eV [26,40], which jointly promote lithium ions to move rapidly rather than accumulate. And the Li/LiCl interface provides a fast pathway due to low migration potential barrier (Fig. 1c), therefore the interface could accelerate the rapid migration of Li+ and facilitate its uniform distribution.

Fig. S5 and Fig. S6 shows the average hysteresis voltages of treated Li and fresh Li electrodes. The results show that treated Li exhibits a lower and smoother voltage hysteresis profile compared to fresh Li. The hysteresis voltage of treated Li remains stable at 31 mV over 500 cycles, while that of the fresh Li spikes to 294 mV over 100 cycles at 1 mA cm−2. The main reason is that the artificial chlorinated SEI composed of PTMG, LiCl and LiZn reduces the Rct and lowers the local current density. Similar average voltage hysteresis - time profile was also observed at 2 mA cm−2 (Fig. S6). In addition, even at high current density of 5 mA cm−2 (Fig. S7), the treated Li can still run stably for more than 500 cycles, implying negligible formation of “dead Li” and Li dendrites at higher currents in treated Li compared to fresh Li. In contrast, the voltage profile of fresh Li exhibits a wide range of fluctuations, with a significant micro-short circuit at 62th cycle. The voltage hysteresis profiles show that fresh Li anode is more easily to generate dendrites and dead Li at higher current densities. It indicates that the excellent physical and chemical properties of the artificial chlorinated hybrid SEI can significantly improve the cycle life of the battery.

The microstructure of the electrode surface largely determines the battery performance [41]. Thus, SEM was employed to investigate the surface morphological properties of treated Li and fresh Li after lithium deposition at different cycle times. Fig. 4f shows the microstructure of the electrode surface of fresh Li after 1st, 10th and 100th plating at 1 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. After 10th lithium deposition, the electrode surface shows significant porosity and undesired mossy lithium. After 100 cycles, the mossy lithium dissolves and severe pulverization occurs on the fresh Li surface, indicating that the SEI loses its protective effect, and nonuniform lithium deposition and uncontrollable dendrite growth occur on the electrode surface. This leads to increased cell impedance and hysteresis voltage consistent with the long-term plating/stripping behavior of symmetric cells. In contrast, the treated Li exhibits dense, smooth surface morphology without obvious mossy lithium and dendrites (Fig. 4f), indicating that the compact and uniform artificial SEI not only regulates the deposition of Li under the mixed layer, but also effectively prevents the direct contact between the organic electrolyte and Li metal. In addition, LiCl, as an important component of the artificial chlorinated hybrid SEI, is insulating, which is not conducive to the nucleation of lithium in the SEI and facilitates the rapid migration of lithium ions, resulting in smooth and uniform lithium deposition. Therefore, in the presence of artificial SEI, the treated Li exhibited stable cycling performance for more than 2000 h in dendrite-free symmetric cells.

The electrochemical stability of treated Li was further investigated using XPS and EIS analyses. Fig. S8 presents the Cl 2p and Li 1 s XPS spectra of the fresh treated Li electrode and those after 100th plating at 1 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. The impurities on the treated Li surface were washed with dimethyl carbonate (DMC). Fig. S8b and d demonstrate that LiCl and LiZn alloys are still present in the hybrid layer after 100th plating, indicating that the Cl and Zn elements are uniformly distributed on the surface of the artificial SEI after cycling, but the deposition behavior of lithium occurs underneath the SEI. It further confirms that the hybrid layer composed of PTMG, LiCl and LiZn alloy has high electrochemical stability. In addition, as shown in Fig. S9, impedance measurements after 10th and 100th cycles present that the Rct of the fresh Li increased apparently compared to the initial condition. This is due to low stability and easy fragility of SEI would cause side reactions and continuous formation of SEI on the surface of Fresh Li after cycles. As a result, the Rct of fresh Li increases rapidly from 32 to 65 Ω from 10th to 100th cycle. In contrast, the Rct of treated Li hardly changed with a low value of 10 Ω after 100 cycles. The same trend of impedance variation was obtained even at a current density of 2ma cm−2 (Fig. S10), indicating the excellent stabilization of the artificially chlorinated hybrid SEI.

To further verify the practical application possibility of the chlorinated hybrid SEI strategy, the treated Li as anode with high loading amount of LiFePO4 (17.4 mg cm−2, 3.0 mAh cm−2) were assembled into full cells. Fig. 5 a shows cycling performance comparison of the full-cells with treated Li and fresh Li anodes at a constant current density of 0.5C. It shows that the treated Li exhibits more stable capacity retention and longer cycling performance than fresh Li. The specific discharge capacity of fresh Li shows a significant decay after 60 cycles, while the cell with treated Li still retains 113.2 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles. The charge/discharge voltage profiles also present distinct polarization for the cell with fresh Li and this phenomenon aggravates seriously at 100th cycle, delivering a low capacity of 53.4 mAh g−1 with a capacity retention rate of only 40.4% (Fig. 5b and c). In the treated Li full cell, the polarization degree has been significantly suppressed, promoting the outstanding capacity retention. In addition, the initial CE of the full cells with treated Li and fresh Li is 90.8% and 80.3%, respectively. In the fresh Li full cell, the low CE is attributed to the inactive lithium loss and unstable SEI, due to the direct contact between lithium metal and the electrolyte (Fig. S12). In contrast, treated Li with artificial SEI comprised of LiZn alloy, LiCl and PTMG exhibits not only high ionic conductivity but also excellent electrochemical stability. Therefore, the treated Li full cell can still maintain a CE close to 100% after 300 cycles. It demonstrates the effectiveness of the artificial chlorinated hybrid layer for practical applications in Li-metal batteries.

In the rate performance test, to avoid the influence of the charging process on the battery capacity, a constant charging current is used at 0.1C (1C = 170 mA g−1), and different discharging current at 0.2C, 0.5C, 1C, 2C and 3C rates are selected for comparison. Fig. 5d shows the rate capability of the treated Li and fresh Li full cells. As the current density increase from 0.2C to 3C, the treated Li full cell exhibits a more stable and higher specific capacity compared to fresh Li. In particular, at a higher discharge rate of 3C, the specific capacities of treated Li and fresh Li cells were 121 mAh g−1 and 95.1 mAh g−1, respectively. Fig. 5e and f corresponds to the charge and discharge voltage curves at different current rates. It can be clearly found that smaller hysteresis voltages are obtained for treated Li anode at all discharge rates, and the advantage is more obvious with the increasing rates from 0.2C to 3C. This is mainly due to the artificial interface layer of chlorination that protects the lithium metal from reacting with the organic electrolyte and reduces the generation of inactive material. In addition, the poor electronic conductivity of LiCl can effectively inhibit the growth of dendrites. Therefore, the treated Li full cell under the protection of chlorinated artificial hybrid SEI is able to obtain high capacity compared with fresh Li.

In summary, we computationally revealed that chlorinated SEI had the ability to guide lithium deposition beneath the artificial modification layer. DFT theoretical calculations indicate that fast ion channels are formed at the LiCl/Li interface, effectively reducing the interfacial resistance and improving Li+ migration rate. Experimentally, the hybrid SEI containing LiZn alloy, LiCl and PTMG components were in situ constructed on the lithium metal surface by a fast dip-coating process, whose chemical and mechanical stability isolates the lithium metal from the intimate contact with the electrolyte and inhibits the growth of lithium dendrites. As a result, the artificially chlorinated hybrid SEI was able to achieve uniform distribution of lithium ions and nucleation under the hybrid layer and cycle stable over 2000 h at 1 mA cm−2 and 1 mAh cm−2 with dendrite-free. Remarkable, outstanding electrochemical performances were obtained in full cell based on high loading LiFePO4 cathode (17.4 mg cm−2, 3.0 mAh cm−2). High specific capacity of 113.2 mAh g−1 and stable CE close to 100% were remained after 300 continuous cycles at 0.5C. This strategy developed a novel method of constructing artificial SEI layers on lithium metal anode, and help to achieve practical applications for high energy density lithium metal batteries, such as Li-S and Li-O2 cells.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of composite lithium metal electrodes
ce:section.ce:para: The entire process of composite electrode preparation is carried out in an argon-filled glove box (H2O < 0.01 ppm, O2 < 0.01 ppm) at room temperature. The lithium metal foil (99.9%, 300 mm) was polished until the surface has a bright metallic luster by lightly scraping with a scalpel. After polishing, the lithium foil was immersed in a 0.167 M ZnCl2 tetrahydrofuran (THF, inhibitor-free; Sigma-Aldrich) solution (within 20 s), and it is worth noting that epichlorohydrin (ECH) should be added 30 min in advance. When the surface of the lithium foil turned completely black, it was carefully removed from the THF solution. The surface impurities of Treated Li were cleaned with THF, then vacuum dried in a glove box at 50 ℃ for 48 h, and finally the chlorinated hybrid SEI on the Li electrode was obtained, and cut into 10 mm or 12 mm diameter circles for stability and electrochemical properties studies. All the reagents mentioned above were not further purified.

X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku D/max-2500, Cu-Kα radiation, λ = 1.50405 Å) was employed to analyze the phase structure of composite lithium metal electrodes from 20° to 80° at room temperature. Before scanning, the samples were sealed tightly with kapton tape to prevent contact with water and oxygen during the test. Raman spectra were tested on a Horiba Raman microscope at frequency between 3200 cm−1 and 400 cm−1. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterizations were performed on K-ALPHA+ with Al Kα (1486.7 eV) radiation. the scanning electron microscope (SEM) and X-ray Energy Dispersive Spectrometer (EDS) mapping were carried out on a JEOL JSM-7610FPlus. After the cycles, the electrolyte remaining on the electrode surface needs to be carefully washed with dimethyl carbonate (DMC) dried for 60 min in an argon-filled glove box. Glow Discharge optical emission spectroscopy (GD-OES) analyses were conducted using a GD Profiler 2 device (Horiba).

Long-term cycle and rate performance measurements of treated Li and fresh Li coin-cells (CR2032) were performed on a LAND CT2001A electrochemical test system at room temperature. The Li-symmetric battery was assembled with two fresh Li or treated Li foils, using Celgard 2400 as the separator, and 50 μL of electrolyte. The electrolyte was 1 M LiTFSI dissolved in a 1:1 vol ratio of DOL and DME with 2% LiNO3. In the full cell, LiFePO4, polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) and super P were mixed in dimethylformamide (DMF) at a mass ratio of 8: 1: 1 to obtain the cathode slurry, which was then uniformly coated on aluminum foil with an active material mass loading of about 17.4 mg cm−2. After drying in a vacuum at 110 °C for 12 h, LiFePO4 was cut into 12 mm diameter disk. In the full cells test, the charge and discharge cutoff voltages were set to 4.2 V and 2.5 V, respectively. In addition, 0.1C constant current charging is used during the rate performance test, facilitating our separate study the stability of the chlorinated hybrid SEI. All the coin cells were assembled in a glove box filled with argon gas (H2O < 0.01 ppm, O2 < 0.01 ppm). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) test was carried out on a 1400 Cell Test System electrochemical workstation with a frequency range of 0.01 Hz to 100 kHz.

All density functional theory calculations were performed using the CASTEP module of Materials Studio of Accelrys Inc (version 5.5). The generalized gradient approximation of Perdew-Burke-Ermzerh function GGA-PEB was used to describe the exchange correlation interaction, the cut-off energy was set to 520 eV, and the k-point was set to fine. To ensure that the surface model and interface model are closer to the real situation, the Li (001) and LiCl (001) were cleaved from the corresponding cell as the stable surface, and a vacuum layer of 15 Å was adopted. In the DFT calculations, the convergence tolerance of the system energy and force were set to 1.0 × 10−5 eV/atom and 2.0 × 10−3 eV/Å, respectively. The self-consistent field operations does not exceed 100 times for each iteration step. The Brillioun zone was integrated using the k-point grid of the Monkhorts - Pack scheme. Moreover, the LST/QST method was applied to search the transition states.

The magnitude of the atomic adsorption energy affects the deposition behavior of lithium atoms during the cycle, which is the adsorption energy,

In order to reveal the motion characteristics of li ions in the artificial SEI, DFT calculated the migration potential barriers of Li ions at the LiCl and LiCl/Li interfaces. The lower the migration potential barrier at the LiCl/Li interface, the easier and faster the lithium ion can pass through the interface layer and nucleate under the interface layer. The transition state of the migration potential barrier is searched by the LST/QST method in CASTEP.
